key_points: Capitol Police Officer Brian Sicknick died of natural causes a day after the January 6 Capitol assault, as announced by the D.C. medical examiner's office.
Sicknick's death was caused by strokes due to a clot in his basilar artery.
He was sprayed with a chemical substance on January 6 and collapsed eight hours later.
The medical examiner classified Sicknick's death as "natural," finding no evidence of internal or external injuries linked to the assault's events.
The full medical examiner's report has not been publicly released.
Capitol Police initially stated Sicknick died from injuries sustained while on duty during the riot.
Capitol Police accepted the finding but emphasized Sicknick died in the line of duty defending the Capitol.
Two suspects were charged with assaulting Sicknick with chemical spray.
Sicknick lay in honor at the Capitol Rotunda and was remembered as a peacekeeper and a humble man by colleagues and leaders.
President Joe Biden and Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer paid tribute to Sicknick at the Capitol.
